segment.source: MD Conversion - Prepare iOS apps for mobile application management with the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool
segment.target: MD Conversion - Prepare iOS apps for mobile application management with the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool

segment.source: MD Conversion - Prepare iOS apps for mobile application management with the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool
segment.target: MD Conversion - Prepare iOS apps for mobile application management with the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool

segment.source: Use the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS to modify the behavior of in-house iOS apps by restricting features of the app without changing the code of the app itself.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS to modify the behavior of in-house iOS apps by restricting features of the app without changing the code of the app itself.

segment.source: The tool is a Mac OS command line application that creates a ‘wrapper’ around an app.
segment.target: The tool is a Mac OS command line application that creates a ‘wrapper’ around an app.

segment.source: Once an app is processed, you can then change the apps functionality using an mobile application management policy that you configure (see Configure and deploy mobile application management policies in the Microsoft Intune console).
segment.target: Once an app is processed, you can then change the apps functionality using an mobile application management policy that you configure (see Configure and deploy mobile application management policies in the Microsoft Intune console).

segment.source: To download the tool, see Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.
segment.target: To download the tool, see Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.

segment.source: Step 1: Fulfill the prerequisites for using the app wrapping tool
segment.target: Step 1: Fulfill the prerequisites for using the app wrapping tool

segment.source: Requirement
segment.target: Requirement

segment.source: Details and more information
segment.target: Details and more information

segment.source: Supported operating system and toolset
segment.target: Supported operating system and toolset

segment.source: You must run the app wrapping tool on a Mac computer that runs OS X 10.8.5 or later, which has the XCode toolset version 5 or later installed.
segment.target: You must run the app wrapping tool on a Mac computer that runs OS X 10.8.5 or later, which has the XCode toolset version 5 or later installed.

segment.source: Signing certificate and provisioning profile
segment.target: Signing certificate and provisioning profile

segment.source: You must have an Apple signing certificate and provisioning profile.
segment.target: You must have an Apple signing certificate and provisioning profile.

segment.source: See your Apple developer documentation.
segment.target: See your Apple developer documentation.

segment.source: Processing an app with the App Wrapping Tool
segment.target: Processing an app with the App Wrapping Tool

segment.source: Apps must be developed and signed by your company, or an independent software vendor (ISV).
segment.target: Apps must be developed and signed by your company, or an independent software vendor (ISV).

segment.source: You cannot use this tool to process apps from the Apple Store.
segment.target: You cannot use this tool to process apps from the Apple Store.

segment.source: Apps must be written for iOS 7.0 or later.
segment.target: Apps must be written for iOS 7.0 or later.

segment.source: Apps must also be in the Position Independent Executable (PIE) format.
segment.target: Apps must also be in the Position Independent Executable (PIE) format.

segment.source: For more information about the PIE format, see your Apple developer documentation.
segment.target: For more information about the PIE format, see your Apple developer documentation.

segment.source: Lastly, the app must have the extension .app, or .ipa format.
segment.target: Lastly, the app must have the extension .app, or .ipa format.

segment.source: Apps the wrapping tool cannot process
segment.target: Apps the wrapping tool cannot process

segment.source: Encrypted apps, unsigned apps, and apps with extended file attributes.
segment.target: Encrypted apps, unsigned apps, and apps with extended file attributes.

segment.source: Apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL)
segment.target: Apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL)

segment.source: If your app uses ADAL, the app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2, and the developer must grant their app access to the Intune Mobile Application Management resource.
segment.target: If your app uses ADAL, the app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2, and the developer must grant their app access to the Intune Mobile Application Management resource.

segment.source: See Information for apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL) in this article for details about how to use ADAL.
segment.target: See Information for apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL) in this article for details about how to use ADAL.

segment.source: Setting entitlements for your app
segment.target: Setting entitlements for your app

segment.source: You must set entitlements, which give the app additional permissions and capabilities beyond those typically granted, before you wrap the app.
segment.target: You must set entitlements, which give the app additional permissions and capabilities beyond those typically granted, before you wrap the app.

segment.source: See Setting app entitlements for instructions.
segment.target: See Setting app entitlements for instructions.

segment.source: Step 2: Install the app wrapping tool
segment.target: Step 2: Install the app wrapping tool

segment.source: From the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS page on the Microsoft Download Center, download the installation file for the app wrapping tool to a Mac computer.
segment.target: From the Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS page on the Microsoft Download Center, download the installation file for the app wrapping tool to a Mac computer.

segment.source: On the Mac computer, double-click the installation file Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.dmg.
segment.target: On the Mac computer, double-click the installation file Microsoft Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.dmg.

segment.source: Click Agree to accept the End User License Agreement (EULA).
segment.target: Click Agree to accept the End User License Agreement (EULA).

segment.source: The installer is mounted and displayed on the Mac computer.
segment.target: The installer is mounted and displayed on the Mac computer.

segment.source: Open the installer and copy the displayed files to a new folder on the Mac computer.
segment.target: Open the installer and copy the displayed files to a new folder on the Mac computer.

segment.source: You can now disconnect the mounted installer drive.
segment.target: You can now disconnect the mounted installer drive.

segment.source: You are now ready to run the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: You are now ready to run the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: Step 3: Run the app wrapping tool
segment.target: Step 3: Run the app wrapping tool

segment.source: On the Mac computer, open a Terminal window and navigate to the folder where you saved the files.
segment.target: On the Mac computer, open a Terminal window and navigate to the folder where you saved the files.

segment.source: Because the executable resides inside the package, you’ll need to run the command as follows:
segment.target: Because the executable resides inside the package, you’ll need to run the command as follows:

segment.source: Some parameters are optional as shown in the table below.
segment.target: Some parameters are optional as shown in the table below.

segment.source: Example: The following example command runs the app wrapping tool on an app named MyApp.ipa.
segment.target: Example: The following example command runs the app wrapping tool on an app named MyApp.ipa.

segment.source: A provisioning profile and SHA-1 hash are specified.
segment.target: A provisioning profile and SHA-1 hash are specified.

segment.source: The processed app is created and stored in the /users/myadmin/Documents on the Mac computer.
segment.target: The processed app is created and stored in the /users/myadmin/Documents on the Mac computer.

segment.source: You can use the following command line properties with the app wrapping tool:
segment.target: You can use the following command line properties with the app wrapping tool:

segment.source: Property
segment.target: Property

segment.source: More information
segment.target: More information

segment.source: -h
segment.target: -h

segment.source: Displays the available command-line properties for the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Displays the available command-line properties for the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: -i
segment.target: -i

segment.source: Specifies the path and file name of the input app.
segment.target: Specifies the path and file name of the input app.

segment.source: -o
segment.target: -o

segment.source: Specifies the path in which to save the processed app.
segment.target: Specifies the path in which to save the processed app.

segment.source: -p
segment.target: -p

segment.source: Specifies the path to your provisioning profile for iOS apps.
segment.target: Specifies the path to your provisioning profile for iOS apps.

segment.source: -c
segment.target: -c

segment.source: Specifies the SHA1 hash of the signing certificate.
segment.target: Specifies the SHA1 hash of the signing certificate.

segment.source: -a
segment.target: -a

segment.source: Client ID of the input app (in GUID format) if the app uses Azure Active Directory Libraries (Optional).
segment.target: Client ID of the input app (in GUID format) if the app uses Azure Active Directory Libraries (Optional).

segment.source: -r
segment.target: -r

segment.source: Redirect URI of the input app if the app uses Azure Active Directory Libraries (Optional).
segment.target: Redirect URI of the input app if the app uses Azure Active Directory Libraries (Optional).

segment.source: -v
segment.target: -v

segment.source: Output verbose messages to the console (Optional).
segment.target: Output verbose messages to the console (Optional).

segment.source: After processing completes, the message The application was successfully wrapped will be displayed.
segment.target: After processing completes, the message The application was successfully wrapped will be displayed.

segment.source: If an error occurs, see Error messages for help.
segment.target: If an error occurs, see Error messages for help.

segment.source: The wrapped app is saved in the output folder you specified previously.
segment.target: The wrapped app is saved in the output folder you specified previously.

segment.source: You can now upload the app into and associate it with a mobile application management policy.
segment.target: You can now upload the app into and associate it with a mobile application management policy.

segment.source: To learn more, see Deploy apps to mobile devices in Microsoft Intune - deleted.
segment.target: To learn more, see Deploy apps to mobile devices in Microsoft Intune - deleted.

segment.source: You must upload the app as a new app.
segment.target: You must upload the app as a new app.

segment.source: You cannot update an older, unwrapped version of the app.
segment.target: You cannot update an older, unwrapped version of the app.

segment.source: You can now deploy the app to your groups, and the app will now run on the device using the app restrictions you specify.
segment.target: You can now deploy the app to your groups, and the app will now run on the device using the app restrictions you specify.

segment.source: Error messages and log files
segment.target: Error messages and log files

segment.source: Use the following information to troubleshoot issues you have with the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Use the following information to troubleshoot issues you have with the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: Error messages
segment.target: Error messages

segment.source: If the app wrapping tool fails to complete successfully, one of the following error messages will be displayed:
segment.target: If the app wrapping tool fails to complete successfully, one of the following error messages will be displayed:

segment.source: Error message
segment.target: Error message

segment.source: More information
segment.target: More information

segment.source: You must specify a valid iOS provisioning profile.
segment.target: You must specify a valid iOS provisioning profile.

segment.source: Your provisioning profile might not be valid.
segment.target: Your provisioning profile might not be valid.

segment.source: Check to make sure you have the correct permissions for devices and that your profile is correctly targeting either development or distribution.
segment.target: Check to make sure you have the correct permissions for devices and that your profile is correctly targeting either development or distribution.

segment.source: Your provisioning profile might also be expired.
segment.target: Your provisioning profile might also be expired.

segment.source: Specify a valid input application name.
segment.target: Specify a valid input application name.

segment.source: Make sure that the input application name you specified is correct.
segment.target: Make sure that the input application name you specified is correct.

segment.source: Specify a valid path to the output application.
segment.target: Specify a valid path to the output application.

segment.source: Make sure that the path to the output application you specified exists, and is correct.
segment.target: Make sure that the path to the output application you specified exists, and is correct.

segment.source: Specify a valid input provisioning profile.
segment.target: Specify a valid input provisioning profile.

segment.source: Make sure you supplied a valid provisioning profile name and extension.
segment.target: Make sure you supplied a valid provisioning profile name and extension.

segment.source: Your provisioning profile might be missing entitlements or you might not have included the –p command-line option.
segment.target: Your provisioning profile might be missing entitlements or you might not have included the –p command-line option.

segment.source: The input application you specified was not found.
segment.target: The input application you specified was not found.

segment.source: Specify a valid input application name and path.
segment.target: Specify a valid input application name and path.

segment.source: Make sure your input app path is valid and exists.
segment.target: Make sure your input app path is valid and exists.

segment.source: Make sure the input app exists at that location.
segment.target: Make sure the input app exists at that location.

segment.source: The input provisioning profile file you specified was not found.
segment.target: The input provisioning profile file you specified was not found.

segment.source: Specify a valid input provisioning profile file.
segment.target: Specify a valid input provisioning profile file.

segment.source: Make sure that the path to the input provisioning file is valid and that the file you specified exists.
segment.target: Make sure that the path to the input provisioning file is valid and that the file you specified exists.

segment.source: The output application folder you specified was not found.
segment.target: The output application folder you specified was not found.

segment.source: Specify a valid path to the output application.
segment.target: Specify a valid path to the output application.

segment.source: Make sure that the output path you specified is valid and exists.
segment.target: Make sure that the output path you specified is valid and exists.

segment.source: Output app does not have .ipa extension.
segment.target: Output app does not have .ipa extension.

segment.source: Only apps with the .app and .ipa extensions are accepted by the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Only apps with the .app and .ipa extensions are accepted by the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: Make sure your output file has a valid extension.
segment.target: Make sure your output file has a valid extension.

segment.source: An invalid signing certificate was specified.
segment.target: An invalid signing certificate was specified.

segment.source: Specify a valid Apple signing certificate.
segment.target: Specify a valid Apple signing certificate.

segment.source: Make sure you’ve downloaded the correct signing certificate from the Apple developer portal.
segment.target: Make sure you’ve downloaded the correct signing certificate from the Apple developer portal.

segment.source: Your certificate might also be expired.
segment.target: Your certificate might also be expired.

segment.source: If your Apple certificate and provisioning profile can be used to correctly sign an app within Xcode, then they are valid for the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: If your Apple certificate and provisioning profile can be used to correctly sign an app within Xcode, then they are valid for the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: The input application you specified is invalid.
segment.target: The input application you specified is invalid.

segment.source: Specify a valid application.
segment.target: Specify a valid application.

segment.source: Make sure you have a valid iOS application that has been compiled as an .app or .ipa file.
segment.target: Make sure you have a valid iOS application that has been compiled as an .app or .ipa file.

segment.source: The input application you specified is encrypted.
segment.target: The input application you specified is encrypted.

segment.source: Specify a valid unencrypted application.
segment.target: Specify a valid unencrypted application.

segment.source: The app wrapping tool does not support encrypted apps.
segment.target: The app wrapping tool does not support encrypted apps.

segment.source: Specify an unencrypted app.
segment.target: Specify an unencrypted app.

segment.source: The input application you specified is not in a Position Independent Executable (PIE) format.
segment.target: The input application you specified is not in a Position Independent Executable (PIE) format.

segment.source: Specify a valid application in PIE format.
segment.target: Specify a valid application in PIE format.

segment.source: Position Independent Executable (PIE) apps can be loaded at a random memory address when run which can have security benefits.
segment.target: Position Independent Executable (PIE) apps can be loaded at a random memory address when run which can have security benefits.

segment.source: For more information, see your Apple Developer documentation.
segment.target: For more information, see your Apple Developer documentation.

segment.source: The input app you specified has already been wrapped.
segment.target: The input app you specified has already been wrapped.

segment.source: Specify a valid unwrapped application.
segment.target: Specify a valid unwrapped application.

segment.source: You cannot process an app that has already been processed by the tool.
segment.target: You cannot process an app that has already been processed by the tool.

segment.source: If you want to process an app again, run the tool using the original version of the app.
segment.target: If you want to process an app again, run the tool using the original version of the app.

segment.source: The input application you specified is not signed.
segment.target: The input application you specified is not signed.

segment.source: Specify a valid signed application.
segment.target: Specify a valid signed application.

segment.source: The app wrapping tool requires apps to be signed.
segment.target: The app wrapping tool requires apps to be signed.

segment.source: Consult your developer documentation to learn how to sign a wrapped app.
segment.target: Consult your developer documentation to learn how to sign a wrapped app.

segment.source: The input application you specified must be in the .ipa or .app format.
segment.target: The input application you specified must be in the .ipa or .app format.

segment.source: Only .app and .ipa extensions are accepted by the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Only .app and .ipa extensions are accepted by the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: Make sure your input file has a valid extension and has been compiled as a .app or .ipa file.
segment.target: Make sure your input file has a valid extension and has been compiled as a .app or .ipa file.

segment.source: The input app you specified has already been wrapped and is on the latest policy template version.
segment.target: The input app you specified has already been wrapped and is on the latest policy template version.

segment.source: The app wrapping tool will not rewrap an existing wrapped app with the latest policy template version.
segment.target: The app wrapping tool will not rewrap an existing wrapped app with the latest policy template version.

segment.source: The given Azure Active Directory Client ID not a well-formed GUID.
segment.target: The given Azure Active Directory Client ID not a well-formed GUID.

segment.source: Please specify a valid Client ID.
segment.target: Please specify a valid Client ID.

segment.source: When using the Client ID parameter, make sure you’ve provided a valid Client ID in GUID format.
segment.target: When using the Client ID parameter, make sure you’ve provided a valid Client ID in GUID format.

segment.source: The given Azure Active Directory reply URI is not a well-formed URI.
segment.target: The given Azure Active Directory reply URI is not a well-formed URI.

segment.source: Please specify a valid reply URI.
segment.target: Please specify a valid reply URI.

segment.source: When using the reply URI command line property, make sure you’ve provided a valid reply URI.
segment.target: When using the reply URI command line property, make sure you’ve provided a valid reply URI.

segment.source: WARNING: You did not specify a SHA1 certificate hash.
segment.target: WARNING: You did not specify a SHA1 certificate hash.

segment.source: Make sure that your wrapped application is signed before deploying.
segment.target: Make sure that your wrapped application is signed before deploying.

segment.source: Ensure that you specify a valid SHA hash (using the –c command line property).
segment.target: Ensure that you specify a valid SHA hash (using the –c command line property).

segment.source: Log files for the app wrapping tool
segment.target: Log files for the app wrapping tool

segment.source: Apps that have been wrapped by using the app wrapping tool generate logs which are written to the iOS client device console.
segment.target: Apps that have been wrapped by using the app wrapping tool generate logs which are written to the iOS client device console.

segment.source: This information is useful in situations where you are having problems with the application and need to diagnose if the issue is related to the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: This information is useful in situations where you are having problems with the application and need to diagnose if the issue is related to the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: To retrieve this information, use the following steps:
segment.target: To retrieve this information, use the following steps:

segment.source: Reproduce the issue by running the app.
segment.target: Reproduce the issue by running the app.

segment.source: Collect the console output by following Apple's instructions for Debugging Deployed iOS Apps.
segment.target: Collect the console output by following Apple's instructions for Debugging Deployed iOS Apps.

segment.source: Filter the saved logs for App Restrictions output by entering the following script into the console:
segment.target: Filter the saved logs for App Restrictions output by entering the following script into the console:

segment.source: You can submit the filtered logs to Microsoft.
segment.target: You can submit the filtered logs to Microsoft.

segment.source: In the log file, the item ‘build version’ represents the build version of Xcode.
segment.target: In the log file, the item ‘build version’ represents the build version of Xcode.

segment.source: Wrapped apps will also present users the option to send logs directly from the device via email after the app crashes.
segment.target: Wrapped apps will also present users the option to send logs directly from the device via email after the app crashes.

segment.source: Users can send the log to you to examine and forward to Microsoft if required.
segment.target: Users can send the log to you to examine and forward to Microsoft if required.

segment.source: Information for apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL)
segment.target: Information for apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL)

segment.source: The information in this section applies only to apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL).
segment.target: The information in this section applies only to apps that use the Azure Active Directory Library (ADAL).

segment.source: If you are unsure if your app uses this library, contact the developer of the app.
segment.target: If you are unsure if your app uses this library, contact the developer of the app.

segment.source: The app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2.
segment.target: The app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2.

segment.source: For apps that use ADAL, the following must be true:
segment.target: For apps that use ADAL, the following must be true:

segment.source: The app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2
segment.target: The app must incorporate an ADAL version greater than or equal to 1.0.2

segment.source: Developers must grant their app access to the Intune Mobile Application Management resource, as described in Steps to follow for apps that use ADAL.
segment.target: Developers must grant their app access to the Intune Mobile Application Management resource, as described in Steps to follow for apps that use ADAL.

segment.source: Overview of identifiers you need to get
segment.target: Overview of identifiers you need to get

segment.source: Apps that use ADAL must register via the Azure management portal to obtain two unique identifiers for their app:
segment.target: Apps that use ADAL must register via the Azure management portal to obtain two unique identifiers for their app:

segment.source: Identifier
segment.target: Identifier

segment.source: More information
segment.target: More information

segment.source: Default value
segment.target: Default value

segment.source: Client ID
segment.target: Client ID

segment.source: A unique GUID identifier is generated for each app after it registers with Azure Active Directory.
segment.target: A unique GUID identifier is generated for each app after it registers with Azure Active Directory.

segment.source: If you know the app's specific client ID, you can specify this value.
segment.target: If you know the app's specific client ID, you can specify this value.

segment.source: Otherwise, the default value must be used.
segment.target: Otherwise, the default value must be used.

segment.source: Redirect URI
segment.target: Redirect URI

segment.source: A URI value that developers can provide when registering their app with Azure Active Directory to ensure that authentication tokens are returned specifically to that endpoint.
segment.target: A URI value that developers can provide when registering their app with Azure Active Directory to ensure that authentication tokens are returned specifically to that endpoint.

segment.source: Supplying a redirect URI is an optional parameter for the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Supplying a redirect URI is an optional parameter for the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: If it is not specified, a default URI will be used.
segment.target: If it is not specified, a default URI will be used.

segment.source: urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob
segment.target: urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob

segment.source: When you do not supply the above values to the tool; the following additional values are automatically used:
segment.target: When you do not supply the above values to the tool; the following additional values are automatically used:

segment.source: Authority URI - https://login.windows.net/common/oauth2/authorize
segment.target: Authority URI - https://login.windows.net/common/oauth2/authorize

segment.source: Resource ID - https://intunemam.microsoft.com
segment.target: Resource ID - https://intunemam.microsoft.com

segment.source: Steps to follow for apps that use ADAL
segment.target: Steps to follow for apps that use ADAL

segment.source: Review Overview of identifiers you need to get to identify the values that you need to get.
segment.target: Review Overview of identifiers you need to get to identify the values that you need to get.

segment.source: Configure access to mobile application management in Azure Active Directory by doing the following:
segment.target: Configure access to mobile application management in Azure Active Directory by doing the following:

segment.source: Log into an existing Azure Active Directory account in the Azure management portal.
segment.target: Log into an existing Azure Active Directory account in the Azure management portal.

segment.source: Click existing LOB application registration in Azure Active Directory.
segment.target: Click existing LOB application registration in Azure Active Directory.

segment.source: In the configure section, choose Configure Access to Web APIs in other applications.
segment.target: In the configure section, choose Configure Access to Web APIs in other applications.

segment.source: In the Permission to other applications section, from the first drop-down list, choose Intune Mobile Application Management.
segment.target: In the Permission to other applications section, from the first drop-down list, choose Intune Mobile Application Management.

segment.source: You can now use the app's Client ID in the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: You can now use the app's Client ID in the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: You can find the app's Client ID in the Azure Active Directory management portal as described in the Overview of identifiers you need to get section.
segment.target: You can find the app's Client ID in the Azure Active Directory management portal as described in the Overview of identifiers you need to get section.

segment.source: Use the Client-ID (using the property –a) and Redirect-URI values as command-line properties in the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Use the Client-ID (using the property –a) and Redirect-URI values as command-line properties in the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: If you do not have these values, the default values are used.
segment.target: If you do not have these values, the default values are used.

segment.source: You must specify both values, or the end user will not be able to successfully authenticate the processed app.
segment.target: You must specify both values, or the end user will not be able to successfully authenticate the processed app.

segment.source: Certificate, provisioning profile, and authentication requirements
segment.target: Certificate, provisioning profile, and authentication requirements

segment.source: Requirement
segment.target: Requirement

segment.source: Details
segment.target: Details

segment.source: Provisioning profile
segment.target: Provisioning profile

segment.source: Make sure that the provisioning profile is valid before you include it - The app wrapping tool does not check whether the provisioning profile is expired when processing an iOS app.
segment.target: Make sure that the provisioning profile is valid before you include it - The app wrapping tool does not check whether the provisioning profile is expired when processing an iOS app.

segment.source: If an expired provisioning profile is specified, the app wrapping tool will include the expired provisioning profile, and you will not know there is a problem until the app fails to install on an iOS device.
segment.target: If an expired provisioning profile is specified, the app wrapping tool will include the expired provisioning profile, and you will not know there is a problem until the app fails to install on an iOS device.

segment.source: Certificate
segment.target: Certificate

segment.source: Make sure that the certificate is valid before you specify it - The tool does not check whether a certificate is expired when processing iOS apps.
segment.target: Make sure that the certificate is valid before you specify it - The tool does not check whether a certificate is expired when processing iOS apps.

segment.source: If the hash for an expired certificate is provided, the tool will process and sign the app, but it will fail to install on devices.
segment.target: If the hash for an expired certificate is provided, the tool will process and sign the app, but it will fail to install on devices.

segment.source: Make sure that the certificate provided for signing the packaged application has a match in the provisioning profile - The tool does not validate if the provisioning profile has a match for the certificate provided for signing the wrapped application.
segment.target: Make sure that the certificate provided for signing the packaged application has a match in the provisioning profile - The tool does not validate if the provisioning profile has a match for the certificate provided for signing the wrapped application.

segment.source: Authentication
segment.target: Authentication

segment.source: A device must have a pin set for encryption to work.
segment.target: A device must have a pin set for encryption to work.

segment.source: On devices to which you have deployed a wrapped application, touching the status bar on the device will require the user to re-authenticate with .
segment.target: On devices to which you have deployed a wrapped application, touching the status bar on the device will require the user to re-authenticate with .

segment.source: The default policy in a wrapped application is authentication on re-launch.
segment.target: The default policy in a wrapped application is authentication on re-launch.

segment.source: iOS handles any external notification (for example a phone call) as exiting the app and then re-launching it.
segment.target: iOS handles any external notification (for example a phone call) as exiting the app and then re-launching it.

segment.source: For wrapped apps, the first user who signs into any wrapped app from the same publisher is cached.
segment.target: For wrapped apps, the first user who signs into any wrapped app from the same publisher is cached.

segment.source: After this point, only that user is allowed to access the app.
segment.target: After this point, only that user is allowed to access the app.

segment.source: To reset the user, the device has to be unenrolled and then re-enrolled.
segment.target: To reset the user, the device has to be unenrolled and then re-enrolled.

segment.source: Troubleshooting and technical notes about ADAP
segment.target: Troubleshooting and technical notes about ADAP

segment.source: If no ADAL resources are found, the tool will include the ADAL dynamic library.
segment.target: If no ADAL resources are found, the tool will include the ADAL dynamic library.

segment.source: The tool will search for the ADAL library with a name of ADALiOS.bundle in the root folder.
segment.target: The tool will search for the ADAL library with a name of ADALiOS.bundle in the root folder.

segment.source: The tool does not search for ADAL binaries (if any) within the app.
segment.target: The tool does not search for ADAL binaries (if any) within the app.

segment.source: If the app links to an outdated version, there may be runtime errors during login if authentication policies are enabled.
segment.target: If the app links to an outdated version, there may be runtime errors during login if authentication policies are enabled.

segment.source: fetches the AAD token to the MAM resource-id for authentication.
segment.target: fetches the AAD token to the MAM resource-id for authentication.

segment.source: However, it is not used in any call that would in-turn verify the validity of the token.
segment.target: However, it is not used in any call that would in-turn verify the validity of the token.

segment.source: only reads the UPN of the signed-in user to determine app access.
segment.target: only reads the UPN of the signed-in user to determine app access.

segment.source: The AAD token is not used for any further service calls.
segment.target: The AAD token is not used for any further service calls.

segment.source: Authentication tokens are shared between apps from the same publisher since they are stored in shared keychain.
segment.target: Authentication tokens are shared between apps from the same publisher since they are stored in shared keychain.

segment.source: If you want to isolate a specific app, then you must use a different signing certificate and provisioning profile for that app.
segment.target: If you want to isolate a specific app, then you must use a different signing certificate and provisioning profile for that app.

segment.source: Double login prompts are prevented if you provide your client application’s Client ID and Redirect URI.
segment.target: Double login prompts are prevented if you provide your client application’s Client ID and Redirect URI.

segment.source: This Client ID needs to be registered to access the published MAM resource ID in the AAD Dashboard.
segment.target: This Client ID needs to be registered to access the published MAM resource ID in the AAD Dashboard.

segment.source: Failure to do so will result in a login failure when the app runs.
segment.target: Failure to do so will result in a login failure when the app runs.

segment.source: Setting app entitlements
segment.target: Setting app entitlements

segment.source: Before wrapping your app, you can grant entitlements to give the app additional permissions and capabilities that exceed what an app typically can do.
segment.target: Before wrapping your app, you can grant entitlements to give the app additional permissions and capabilities that exceed what an app typically can do.

segment.source: An entitlement file is used during code signing to specify special permissions within your app (for example, access to a shared keychain).
segment.target: An entitlement file is used during code signing to specify special permissions within your app (for example, access to a shared keychain).

segment.source: Specific app services, called capabilities, are enabled within Xcode during app development.
segment.target: Specific app services, called capabilities, are enabled within Xcode during app development.

segment.source: Once enabled, the capabilities are reflected in your entitlements file.
segment.target: Once enabled, the capabilities are reflected in your entitlements file.

segment.source: For more information about entitlements and capabilities, see Adding Capabilities in the iOS Developer Library.
segment.target: For more information about entitlements and capabilities, see Adding Capabilities in the iOS Developer Library.

segment.source: For a complete list of supported capabilities, see Supported capabilities.
segment.target: For a complete list of supported capabilities, see Supported capabilities.

segment.source: Supported capabilities for the App Wrapping Tool for iOS
segment.target: Supported capabilities for the App Wrapping Tool for iOS

segment.source: Capability
segment.target: Capability

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Recommended guidance
segment.target: Recommended guidance

segment.source: App Groups
segment.target: App Groups

segment.source: Use app groups to allow multiple apps to access shared containers and allow additional inter-process communication between apps.
segment.target: Use app groups to allow multiple apps to access shared containers and allow additional inter-process communication between apps.

segment.source: To enable app groups, open the Capabilities pane and click the ON switch in the App Groups section.
segment.target: To enable app groups, open the Capabilities pane and click the ON switch in the App Groups section.

segment.source: You can add app groups or select existing ones.
segment.target: You can add app groups or select existing ones.

segment.source: When using App Groups, use reverse DNS notation:
segment.target: When using App Groups, use reverse DNS notation:

segment.source: group.com.companyName.AppGroup
segment.target: group.com.companyName.AppGroup

segment.source: Background Modes
segment.target: Background Modes

segment.source: Enabling background modes allows your iOS app to continue running in the background.
segment.target: Enabling background modes allows your iOS app to continue running in the background.

segment.source: Data Protection
segment.target: Data Protection

segment.source: Data protection adds a level of security to files stored on disk by your iOS app.
segment.target: Data protection adds a level of security to files stored on disk by your iOS app.

segment.source: Data protection uses the built-in encryption hardware present on specific devices to store files in an encrypted format on disk.
segment.target: Data protection uses the built-in encryption hardware present on specific devices to store files in an encrypted format on disk.

segment.source: Your app needs to be provisioned to use data protection.
segment.target: Your app needs to be provisioned to use data protection.

segment.source: In-App Purchase
segment.target: In-App Purchase

segment.source: In-App purchase embeds a store directly into your app by enabling you to connect to the store and securely process payments from the user.
segment.target: In-App purchase embeds a store directly into your app by enabling you to connect to the store and securely process payments from the user.

segment.source: You can use In-App Purchase to collect payment for enhanced functionality or for additional content usable by your app.
segment.target: You can use In-App Purchase to collect payment for enhanced functionality or for additional content usable by your app.

segment.source: Keychain Sharing
segment.target: Keychain Sharing

segment.source: Enabling keychain sharing allows your app to share passwords in the keychain with other apps developed by your team.
segment.target: Enabling keychain sharing allows your app to share passwords in the keychain with other apps developed by your team.

segment.source: When using Keychain Sharing, use reverse DNS notation:
segment.target: When using Keychain Sharing, use reverse DNS notation:

segment.source: com.companyName.KeychainGroup
segment.target: com.companyName.KeychainGroup

segment.source: Personal VPN
segment.target: Personal VPN

segment.source: Enable personal VPN to allow your app to create and control a custom system VPN configuration using the Network Extension framework.
segment.target: Enable personal VPN to allow your app to create and control a custom system VPN configuration using the Network Extension framework.

segment.source: Push Notifications
segment.target: Push Notifications

segment.source: Apple Push Notification service (APNs) allows an app that isn’t running in the foreground to notify the user that it has information for the user.
segment.target: Apple Push Notification service (APNs) allows an app that isn’t running in the foreground to notify the user that it has information for the user.

segment.source: For push notifications to work, you need to use an app-specific provisioning profile.
segment.target: For push notifications to work, you need to use an app-specific provisioning profile.

segment.source: Follow the steps in the Apple developer documentation.
segment.target: Follow the steps in the Apple developer documentation.

segment.source: Wireless Accessory Configuration
segment.target: Wireless Accessory Configuration

segment.source: Enabling wireless accessory configuration adds the External Accessory framework to your project and allows your app to configure MFi Wi-Fi accessories.
segment.target: Enabling wireless accessory configuration adds the External Accessory framework to your project and allows your app to configure MFi Wi-Fi accessories.

segment.source: Steps to enable entitlements
segment.target: Steps to enable entitlements

segment.source: Enable capabilities in your app:
segment.target: Enable capabilities in your app:

segment.source: In Xcode, navigate to your app’s target, and click the Capabilities pane.
segment.target: In Xcode, navigate to your app’s target, and click the Capabilities pane.

segment.source: Turn on the appropriate capabilities.
segment.target: Turn on the appropriate capabilities.

segment.source: For detailed information about each capability and how to determine the correct values, see Adding Capabilities in the iOS Developer Library.
segment.target: For detailed information about each capability and how to determine the correct values, see Adding Capabilities in the iOS Developer Library.

segment.source: Note any IDs that you created during the process.
segment.target: Note any IDs that you created during the process.

segment.source: Build and sign your app to be wrapped.
segment.target: Build and sign your app to be wrapped.

segment.source: Enable entitlements in your provisioning profile:
segment.target: Enable entitlements in your provisioning profile:

segment.source: Log in to the Apple Developer Member Center.
segment.target: Log in to the Apple Developer Member Center.

segment.source: Create a provisioning profile for your app.
segment.target: Create a provisioning profile for your app.

segment.source: For instructions, see How to Obtain the Prerequisites for the Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.
segment.target: For instructions, see How to Obtain the Prerequisites for the Intune App Wrapping Tool for iOS.

segment.source: In your provisioning profile, enable the same entitlements that you have in your app.
segment.target: In your provisioning profile, enable the same entitlements that you have in your app.

segment.source: You will need to supply the same IDs that you specified during the development of your app.
segment.target: You will need to supply the same IDs that you specified during the development of your app.

segment.source: Complete the provisioning profile wizard and download your file.
segment.target: Complete the provisioning profile wizard and download your file.

segment.source: Ensure that you have satisfied all the prerequisites, and then wrap the app.
segment.target: Ensure that you have satisfied all the prerequisites, and then wrap the app.

segment.source: Troubleshooting common errors with entitlements
segment.target: Troubleshooting common errors with entitlements

segment.source: If the App Wrapping Tool for iOS displays an entitlement error, try the following troubleshooting steps.
segment.target: If the App Wrapping Tool for iOS displays an entitlement error, try the following troubleshooting steps.

segment.source: Issue
segment.target: Issue

segment.source: Cause
segment.target: Cause

segment.source: Resolution
segment.target: Resolution

segment.source: Failed to parse entitlements generated from the input application.
segment.target: Failed to parse entitlements generated from the input application.

segment.source: The App Wrapping Tool cannot read the entitlements file that was extracted from the app.
segment.target: The App Wrapping Tool cannot read the entitlements file that was extracted from the app.

segment.source: The entitlements file might be malformed.
segment.target: The entitlements file might be malformed.

segment.source: Inspect the entitlements file for your app.
segment.target: Inspect the entitlements file for your app.

segment.source: To do so, follow the instructions detailed below.
segment.target: To do so, follow the instructions detailed below.

segment.source: When inspecting the entitlements file, check for any malformed syntax.
segment.target: When inspecting the entitlements file, check for any malformed syntax.

segment.source: The file should be in XML format.
segment.target: The file should be in XML format.

segment.source: Entitlements are missing in the provisioning profile (missing entitlements are listed).
segment.target: Entitlements are missing in the provisioning profile (missing entitlements are listed).

segment.source: Repackage the app with a provisioning profile that has these entitlements.
segment.target: Repackage the app with a provisioning profile that has these entitlements.

segment.source: There is a mismatch between the entitlements enabled in the provisioning profile and the capabilities enabled in the app.
segment.target: There is a mismatch between the entitlements enabled in the provisioning profile and the capabilities enabled in the app.

segment.source: This mismatch also applies to the IDs associated with particular capabilities (i.e., App Groups, Keychain Access etc).
segment.target: This mismatch also applies to the IDs associated with particular capabilities (i.e., App Groups, Keychain Access etc).

segment.source: Generally, you can create a new provisioning profile that enables the same capabilities as the app.
segment.target: Generally, you can create a new provisioning profile that enables the same capabilities as the app.

segment.source: When IDs between the profile and app don't match, the App Wrapping Tool will replace the IDs if it is able to.
segment.target: When IDs between the profile and app don't match, the App Wrapping Tool will replace the IDs if it is able to.

segment.source: If you still get this error after creating a new provisioning profile, you can try removing entitlements from the app by using the –e parameter (see Using the –e parameter to remove entitlements from an app.
segment.target: If you still get this error after creating a new provisioning profile, you can try removing entitlements from the app by using the –e parameter (see Using the –e parameter to remove entitlements from an app.

segment.source: Finding the existing entitlements of a signed app
segment.target: Finding the existing entitlements of a signed app

segment.source: To review the existing entitlements of a signed app and provisioning profile:
segment.target: To review the existing entitlements of a signed app and provisioning profile:

segment.source: Find the .ipa file and change its the extension to .zip.
segment.target: Find the .ipa file and change its the extension to .zip.

segment.source: Expand the .zip file.
segment.target: Expand the .zip file.

segment.source: This will produce a Payload folder containing your .app bundle.
segment.target: This will produce a Payload folder containing your .app bundle.

segment.source: Use the codesign tool to check the entitlements on the .app bundle like this:
segment.target: Use the codesign tool to check the entitlements on the .app bundle like this:

segment.source: where is the actual name of your .app bundle.
segment.target: where is the actual name of your .app bundle.

segment.source: Use the security tool to check the entitlements of the app's embedded provisioning profile:
segment.target: Use the security tool to check the entitlements of the app's embedded provisioning profile:

segment.source: where is the actual name of your .app bundle.
segment.target: where is the actual name of your .app bundle.

segment.source: Using the –e parameter to remove entitlements from an app
segment.target: Using the –e parameter to remove entitlements from an app

segment.source: This command removes any enabled capabilities in the app that are not in the entitlements file.
segment.target: This command removes any enabled capabilities in the app that are not in the entitlements file.

segment.source: If you remove capabilities that are being used by the app, it can break your app.
segment.target: If you remove capabilities that are being used by the app, it can break your app.

segment.source: An example of where you might remove missing capabilities is if you have a vendor-produced app that has all capabilities by default.
segment.target: An example of where you might remove missing capabilities is if you have a vendor-produced app that has all capabilities by default.

segment.source: Security and privacy for the app wrapping tool
segment.target: Security and privacy for the app wrapping tool

segment.source: Use the following security and privacy best practices when you use the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: Use the following security and privacy best practices when you use the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: The signing certificate, provisioning profile and the line-of-business app you specify must be on the same Mac computer that you use to run the app wrapping tool.
segment.target: The signing certificate, provisioning profile and the line-of-business app you specify must be on the same Mac computer that you use to run the app wrapping tool.

segment.source: If the files are on a UNC path, ensure that these are accessible from the Mac computer.
segment.target: If the files are on a UNC path, ensure that these are accessible from the Mac computer.

segment.source: The path must be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.
segment.target: The path must be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.

segment.source: The wrapped application imported into the console should be on the same computer that you run the tool on.
segment.target: The wrapped application imported into the console should be on the same computer that you run the tool on.

segment.source: If the file is on a UNC path, ensure that it is accessible on the computer running the console.
segment.target: If the file is on a UNC path, ensure that it is accessible on the computer running the console.

segment.source: The path must be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.
segment.target: The path must be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.

segment.source: The environment where the app wrapping tool is downloaded from the Microsoft Download Center site needs to be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.
segment.target: The environment where the app wrapping tool is downloaded from the Microsoft Download Center site needs to be secured via IPsec or SMB signing.

segment.source: The app you process must come from a trust-worthy source to ensure protection against attacks.
segment.target: The app you process must come from a trust-worthy source to ensure protection against attacks.

segment.source: Ensure that the output folder you specify in the app wrapping tool is secured, particularly if it is a remote folder.
segment.target: Ensure that the output folder you specify in the app wrapping tool is secured, particularly if it is a remote folder.

segment.source: iOS apps that include a file upload dialog box can allow users to circumvent cut, copy and paste restrictions applied to the app.
segment.target: iOS apps that include a file upload dialog box can allow users to circumvent cut, copy and paste restrictions applied to the app.

segment.source: For example, a user could use the file upload dialog box to upload a screenshot of the app data.
segment.target: For example, a user could use the file upload dialog box to upload a screenshot of the app data.

segment.source: When users monitor the documents folder on their device from within a wrapped app, they might see a folder named .msftintuneapplauncher.
segment.target: When users monitor the documents folder on their device from within a wrapped app, they might see a folder named .msftintuneapplauncher.

segment.source: If this folder is changed or deleted, this might affect the correct functioning of restricted apps.
segment.target: If this folder is changed or deleted, this might affect the correct functioning of restricted apps.

segment.source: See Also
segment.target: See Also

segment.source: Configure and deploy mobile application management policies in the Microsoft Intune console
segment.target: Configure and deploy mobile application management policies in the Microsoft Intune console
